Risks and Assumptions 

Subprojects  under  the  original  and  supplementary  loans  must 
have  a  minimum  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  12%  to  be 
eligible  for  ADB  financing.  The  direct  benefits  of  the  Project  will 
accrue  from  reduced  vehicle  operating  costs  and  time  savings. 
Indirect benefits will include improved access of rural communities 
to  basic  social  facilities,  as  well  as  improved  socioeconomic 
conditions in the areas served by the upgraded roads. 
 
The completion of the remaining subproject is subject to technical 
risks  that  are  largely  within  the  control  of  the  Executing  Agency. 
These  risks  can  be  satisfactorily  mitigated  through  sound  project 
management and supervision.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
supplementary  loan  to  the  Republic  of  the  Fiji  Islands  for  the  Third  Road  Upgrading  (Sector) 
Project (FRUP III).1 
 
 

II. 

THE APPROVED PROJECT 

Project Rationale 

 
A. 
 
2. 
Transport  services for both  passengers  and freight on  the  main  islands of  Vanua Levu 
and  Viti  Levu  rely  heavily  on  roads.  Although  the  road  network  is  largely  complete,  however, 
much of it is built to a low standard. Travel by road takes longer, transported goods are prone to 
damage,  and  socioeconomic  development  suffers.  Heavy  vehicles  on  roads  not  designed  for 
the growing traffic volume and axle loads also do serious harm. On the other hand, because of 
inadequate capacity on some national trunk roads, particularly circular roads and wharf access 
roads,  uneconomic  routes  are  often  chosen.  Rising  transport  costs,  which  hinder  economic 
growth, make the upgrading of roads necessary. The subprojects under FRUP Ill were selected 
on  the  basis  of  passenger  traffic  volume,  the  transport  requirements  of  international  and 
domestic trade, and demand created by tourism. 
 
3. 
The Asian  Development Bank’s  (ADB’s)  operational  strategy supports  the  Government 
in  its  policy  of  improving  transport  infrastructure  in  the  wider  economic  policy  context  of 
promoting  private  sector  development,  reducing  regional  inequalities,  and  delivering  better 
social  services.  Road  upgrading  is  a  key  component  of  the  National  Transport  Sector  Plan, 
consistent with ADB’s policy of supporting high-yielding projects. ADB’s aim in the Pacific region 
continues  to  be  the  creation  of  an  environment  of  improved  productivity,  increased  private 
sector investment, and sustained economic growth. In line with ADB’s strategy for the Pacific,2 
FRUP  III  (the  Project)  addressed  the  improvement  of  physical  infrastructure,  a  key  factor  in 
economic  growth.  Through  associated  technical  assistance  (TA),3 ADB  supported  significant 
policy reform and capacity building in the sector. The background, policy issues, sector analysis, 
and  institutional  framework  are  fully  described  in  the  report  and  recommendation  of  the 
President for the original loan. 
 
B. 
 
 

Objectives and Scope of the Original Project 

Objectives 

1. 

4. 
The original Project was aimed at helping the Government to (i) improve the efficiency of 
road sector services and increase private sector participation, and (ii) improve the management 
of  road assets  and  sector  resources.  The  intent was  to  reduce  transport  sector  constraints  on 
economic  development,  and  thus  improve  the  economic  returns  on  transport  infrastructure.

6. 
In  addition  to  these  project  components,  associated  TA  (footnote  3)  was  provided  to 
build  road  sector  capacity  by  (i)  reorganizing  the  Public  Works  Department  of  the  Ministry  of 
Works and Transport in the context of the new Public Enterprise Act; (ii) establishing the Land 
Transport  Authority  under  the  land  Transport  Bill,  merging  the  Central  Traffic  Authority,  the 
Transport  Control  Board,  and  the  Principal  Licensing  Authority  into  a  single,  self-funding, 
integrated,  and  commercial  Land  Transport  Authority;  and  (iii)  building  the  capacity  of 
stakeholders to implement the Fiji Road Safety Action Plan. 
 
C. 
 
The  total  cost  of  the  Project,  including  interest  and  charges  on  the  ADB  loan  during 
7. 
construction,  was  estimated  at  US$90  million  equivalent—US$39.7  million  (about  44%)  in 
foreign  exchange  and  US$50.3  million  equivalent  (about  56%)  in  local  currency.  The  detailed 
original and revised cost estimate is shown in Table 1. 
 

Original Cost Estimates and Financing Plan 

8. 
The ADB loan of US$40.0 million, about 44% of the project cost, comprised (i) US$34.3 
million  in  civil  works  for  the  road  upgrading  subprojects  (60%  of  category  costs);  (ii)  US$3.5 
million in road rehabilitation (35% of category costs); (iii) US$1.2 million equivalent in civil works 
for  safety  improvements  (34%  of  category  costs);  and  (iv)  US$1.0  million  equivalent  in 
specialized  maintenance  and  laboratory  equipment  (100%  of  category  costs).  The  rest  of  the 
project costs, including interest during construction, were to be met from the Government’s own 
resources. 
 

2 

 

 

 The US dollar loan came from ADB’s ordinary capital resources. It had an amortization 
9. 
period  of  25  years  including  a  grace  period  of  5  years,  and  carried  interest  determined 
according  to  ADB’s  pool-based  variable  lending  rate  system  for  US  dollar  loans  and  a  yearly 
commitment charge of 0.75%. In 2002, the undisbursed balance of the loan was transferred to

plan is in Table 2.

Status and Progress of Project Implementation 

The status of project implementation is as follows: 

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

(iv) 

(v) 

50 km of roads have been upgraded, out of the expected 100 km. A subproject 
(the  upgrading  of  the  Kings  and  Lodoni  roads,  hereinafter  referred  to  as  “the 
subproject”) for the balance of 50 km is ongoing and is about 50% complete. 
120 km of road rehabilitation has been completed, 40 km more than the expected 
output of 80 km. This work was completed by December 2005, within the activity 
category budget. 
All civil works for road safety improvements in road infrastructure were completed 
by December 2005. 
All  specialized  road  maintenance  and  laboratory  equipment  was  procured  by 
December 2005. 
All consulting services, except for those needed for the construction supervision 
of the ongoing subproject, were delivered by December 2005. 

 
The  associated  TA  (footnote  3)  was  completed  in  June  2005.  Its  intended  objectives 
11. 
were generally achieved and the TA was rated partly successful.4 The TA assisted the Ministry 
of  Works  and  Transport  in  developing  and  implementing  institutional  and  policy  reform  by 
establishing  the  Land  Transport  Authority  and  the  Department  of  National  Roads  (the  latter 
being  the  first  stage  of  a  two-step  process  to  establish  a  Fiji  Roads  Authority).  But  the 
implementation  time  frame  was  considerably  extended  and  the  institutional  reform  was  only 
partly accomplished. The reform efforts were to continue under a proposed loan for the Fourth 
Road  Upgrading  (Sector)  Project  (FRUP  IV)  and  associated  TA for  Road  Sector  Performance 
Improvement. Together these were to support the transition of the roads authority from a public 
sector road agency to a statutory authority, with maximum involvement from the private sector 
and  performance-based  management.  Unfortunately,  ADB’s  reengagement  approach5 halted 
the processing of the FRUP IV and much of the momentum for the reform of the road transport 
sector was lost. The process should be revived once reengagement allows FRUP IV to proceed. 
 
12. 
Efforts  at  systematic  and  responsive  road  asset  management  under  the  Project  were 
generally  successful,  but  still  require  the  following  elements  for  long-term  sustainability: 
(i) government  commitment  to  fully  fund  road  maintenance,  which  depends  in  part  on  a 
dedicated stream of road funding; (ii) a continuing human resources program to recruit and train 
staff  and  replace  incumbents  who  are  promoted  or  move  to  other  jobs;  (iii)  government 
budgetary support,  including  the use  of  external suppliers,  to  maintain  software and hardware 
systems so these do not become outdated or obsolete; (iv) rebranding and reissue of manuals 
and  guidelines  prepared  for  the  Public Works  Department;  (v)  a  formalized  and  appropriately 
funded bridge replacement program; (vi) a dedicated budget item for emergency maintenance;

 (vii)  quality  control  systems  for  force  account  and  contracted  maintenance  works;  (viii)  more 
timely,  complete,  and  accurate  entry  of  data  on  road  inventory  and  condition  in  the  divisions; 
(ix) integrated  road  asset  management  and  financial  information  systems;  and  (x)  support  for 
the outsourcing of maintenance activities through the training of Department of National Roads 
(DNR)  staff  in  contract  supervision,  and  of  domestic  contractors  in  labor,  plant,  and  materials 
management,  estimation, and  business  management. While  the Project  improved  capacity for 
road asset management, the Executing Agency (EA) was unable to retain or replace staff, partly 
because momentum toward the long-term sustainability of institutional arrangements for sector 
management was lost. The EA is now looking into twinning arrangements to firm up its position 
and help it to move forward in a way that accords with plans to establish a roads authority. The 
Project  also  provided  only  limited  opportunities  for  domestic  contractors  in  small-scale  civil 
works  including  road  rehabilitation  and  road  safety  improvements.  One  reason  was  the 
preponderance  of  work  under  force  account,  beyond  the  level  foreseen  at  appraisal.  Private 
sector  capacity  has  thus  diminished  as  the  few  opportunities  have  discouraged  investment  in 
new  equipment. Government  has  therefore  had  to  rely  even  more on  works by force account, 
contrary  to  the  aims  of  the  Project.  In  subsequent  projects,  contracts  suitable  in  scale  for  the 
local contracting industry should be included in the implementation plan.

Eleven  km  of  road,  including  earthworks, drainage, and pavement,  is being  built under

16. 
The Government has received bids for two other contracts—(i) the construction of base 
course  and  seal  over  29  km  of  the  subproject;  and  (ii)  the  construction  of  10  km  of  road, 
including  earthworks,  drainage,  and  pavement.  The  bids  conformed  to  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time) including prior review of bidding documents by 
ADB.  
 
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED SUPPLEMENTARY FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE 

The Cost Overrun 

 
A. 
 
17. 
The  cost  of  completing  the  Project  is  now  estimated  to  be  US$162.1  million,  US$72.1 
million more than originally expected. The cost overrun is almost entirely due to the increased 

4 

 

 

 cost  of  completing  the  subproject  (the  civil  works  for  the  upgrading  of  the  Kings  and  Lodoni 
roads).  
 
18. 
In January 2001, the subproject was awarded as a single contract through international 
competitive bidding (ICB).6 When the bids were opened, the US dollar was relatively strong7 and 
it was thought that the cost of the subproject, although large by Fiji standards, could comfortably 
be accommodated within the budget for the Project. At the same time, with anticipated savings 
from the strong US dollar, the EA increased the length of road rehabilitation under the Project 
from a planned 80 km to 120 km. The increase was achieved without exceeding the budget for 
the road rehabilitation category of the original loan. 
 
19. 
By  the  end  of  2005,  the  Project  had  been  completed  except  for  the  subproject,  which 
was  only  35%  complete.  The  unit  rates  under  the  contract  had  gone  up  by  about  28%,  in 
accordance with a rise and fall provision, and the exchange rate had weakened. The estimated 
final  cost  had  jumped  from  F$57.3  million  (US$28.1  million  at  bid  opening)  to  F$74  million 
(about  US$41.5  million).  Even  with  the  substantial  increase,  the  cost  overrun  for  the  Project 
would have been only about US$6 million, within the absorptive capacity of the Borrower. 
 
20. 
However,  the  contractor  stopped  working  in  August  2005  when  the  EA  deducted 
liquidated  damages  from  interim  payments  because  of  the  delay.  After  issuing  contractually 
required  notices  in  an  effort  to  persuade  the  contractor  to  resume  working,  the  supervising 
engineer certified to the EA that the contract had been breached by the contractor and could be 
terminated  by  the  EA.  The  Government  formed  a  cabinet  subcommittee  in  October 2005  to 
review the circumstances surrounding the contractor’s decision to withdraw from the Project and 
to consider alternative arrangements for completing the work. The committee decided that the 
contractor had no reasonable excuse for abandoning the work, and agreed with the supervising 
engineer that claims for additional time and payment were groundless. The EA terminated the 
contract in March 2006. While the committee’s deliberations took some time, the EA proceeded 
in  parallel  to  prepare  a  revised  procurement  plan  and  associated  bidding  documents  for 
completing the works, thereby minimizing further delays. 
 
21. 
ADB approved  the  revised procurement plan for completing  the  works,  comprising five 
ICB  packages  and one force account  package. Bids  were  invited for  the first  three of the five 
ICB  contracts  in  2006  but  the  accepted  tender  prices  were  significantly  above  the  rates  and 
prices  in  the  original  contract.  The  original  contract  price  was  based  on  prevailing  fuel  and 
materials prices and the relatively lower labor and management costs available to the contractor 
from  the  People’s  Republic  of  China.  All  construction  inputs  have  since  undergone  further 
significant cost increases, particularly in fuel, oil, and materials costs (by a factor of at least two) 
over the last 2 years, such that the contract rates for the final two contracts are now three to four 
times higher than those in the original contract. With the delays caused by the poor performance 
of the contractor, the termination process, and the procurement of the new contract packages, 
the Project is not expected to be completed before October 2011. 
 
22. 
The  base  cost  of  completing  the  subproject  is  therefore  estimated  to  have  risen  from 
US$28.1  million  to  about  US$87.0  million  (excluding  project  management  and  supervision 
costs), or by US$58.9 million. The original financing plan provided for a civil works component

23. 
The  Government  has  given  notice  to  the  original  contractor  that  it  intends  to  pursue  a 
claim  against  it,  in accordance  with the  contract,  to  recover  the additional costs  of  completing 
the work, over and above the cost that would have been incurred had the work been completed 
at the rates and prices stated in the original contract. Such a claim cannot be pursued, however, 
until the actual cost of completing the work is known, and has been certified by the engineer for 
the contract. The work is not expected to be completed before October 2011, and the claim will 
almost certainly be resisted and require arbitration. This is likely to take a further 2 years, with 
uncertain  outcome,  given  the  nature  of  the  proceedings  and  the  likelihood  of  counterclaims 
against  the  Government  by  the  contractor.  While  the  Government  may  ultimately  succeed  in 
recovering the cost overrun (in whole or in part), the supplementary finance is needed now to 
ensure  the  completion  of  the  subproject  within  a  reasonable  time  and  to  prevent  the 
deterioration  of  partially  completed  work.  Given  the  substantial  backlog  of  road  rehabilitation 
work,  the  Government has agreed  that  if  it  is  able  to  recover  the  cost  overrun,  in  whole  or  in 
part, from  the  original  contractor,  the sums  will  be applied  to the extent  necessary,   to  priority 
road rehabilitation as defined by the road asset management system, and to ensure adequate 
funding of road maintenance. 
 
B. 
 
Only  2  km  of  a  total  of  50  km  of  the  subproject  has  been  sealed  so  far;  the  rest  is  in 
24. 
varying  stages  of  completion.  In  all  other  areas,  the  pavement  has  either  been  partially 
completed  to  the  subbase  (lower  pavement)  level  or  not  been  started.  Partially  completed 
pavement cannot carry heavy axle loads and will suffer from accelerated deterioration, resulting 
in  loss  of  the  investment  made  so far.  Upgrading  a  road  to  sealed  standard  has  the  principal 
benefit  of  reducing  vehicle  operating  costs  by  reducing  roughness,  improving  geometry,  and 
shortening  route  length.  The  partially  completed  work  captured  some  route-length  reductions 
and  improvements  in  geometry,  but  the  gravel  pavement  is  still  rough  and  vehicle  operating 
costs remain high. All bridges—16 in all—were completed by August 2008. Thirteen are in use, 
but three cannot be used until the road realignments have been completed. 
 
25. 
The  civil  works  under  the  subproject  will  have  an  impact  on  economic  and  social 
development, and on hardship and poverty reduction in the areas served by the roads. As the 
Subproject  is  a  significant part  of  the  overall  road  upgrading  component, failure to  complete  it 
will significantly affect the overall impact of the Project. 
 
C. 
 
26. 
The  development  policy  objectives  set  out  in  the  Government’s  draft  Strategic 
Development  Plan  2007–2011  center  on  the  development  of  efficient  and  cost-effective 
infrastructure for economic and social development and private sector investment, accompanied 
by  institutional  strengthening  for  more  capable  and  better-quality  facilities  and  services. 
Strategies for achieving these objectives include improving access to safe, efficient, affordable, 
and environmentally sustainable transport services; and reducing the cost of transporting people 
and  goods.  The  three  primary  goals  of  the  plan  are  sustained  growth,  rural  and  outer  island 
development,  and  efficient  transport  services.  The  Government’s  overall  aim  for  the  transport 
subsector,  given  in  the  Review  and  Update of the  Transport  Sector  Plan  (2004), supports  the 

Rationale for the Completion of the Kings and Lodoni Roads Subproject 

6 

 

 

 national development objectives by targeting the development of an integrated transport system 
that is safe, efficient, affordable, accessible, and economically and environmentally sustainable. 
 
The  results-based  framework  of  the  country  strategy  and  program  update  2006–20088 
27. 
approved in March 2006 supports the Government’s objectives of (i) generating private sector–
led  growth  through  sound  macroeconomic  policies,  infrastructure,  and  alternative  livelihoods; 
(ii) delivering affordable basic social services through support for water and sanitation services, 
and  improvements  in  local governance;  and  (iii) establishing effective development  institutions 
through a sequenced and interlinked TA package. The preparation of a new country partnership 
strategy 2007–2011 to support the country’s Strategic Development Plan began in 2006 but was 
suspended on 5 December of that year, after a peaceful takeover of the democratically elected 
government by the Fiji military forces. 
 
28. 
The  Kings  and  Lodoni  roads  serve  the  rural  and  impoverished  areas  of  the  east  and 
northeast of the main island, Viti Levu. Kings Road (29 km from Korovou to Nayavu), the final 
section  of  the  circum-insular  highway  to  be  upgraded  to  sealed  standard,  will  benefit  rural 
communities  by  establishing  regular  access  to  markets  and  services  in  the  Suva  area.  The 
majority  of  the  rural  population  is  engaged  in  subsistence  farming;  some  sell  surplus  garden 
produce at  roadside  stalls  to augment  their  income.  Previous  road-upgrading programs  in  the 
Fiji Islands have shown that upgrading Kings Road will expand income-generating opportunities, 
particularly for small-scale fruit and vegetable farmers in the surrounding Wainibuka valley, and 
reduce transport costs for dairy farmers along the southern part of the route. Improved access 
to Suva from the northeast of Viti Levu will also make the costs of transportation to health and 
educational  services  more  affordable 
this  underdeveloped  and 
disadvantaged area. 
 
29. 
Lodoni  Road  (21  km)  serves  the  east  coast  to  the  north  of  Korovou.  The  rural 
communities  here  will  likewise  benefit  from  easier  access  to  the  greater  Suva  area,  as  will 
students  from  two  large  state  boarding  schools  served  by  the  road.  The  link  between  the 
international port of Suva and the roll-on, roll-off jetty at Natovi will improve, and land transport 
costs will be reduced. The Natovi jetty serves both the second-largest island of Viti Levu and the 
island of Ovalau. The reduction in land transport costs and the shorter sea route to Vanua Levu 
(5 hours, as opposed to 10 hours from Suva) will allow goods and services to be priced lower.

 ADB’s Reengagement Strategy 

D. 
 
32. 
ADB is implementing a two-stage reengagement strategy (footnote 5) in the Fiji Islands 
following  the  political  crisis  in  2006.  In  the  first  stage,  ADB  has  continued  to  support  ongoing 
operations, as it has ascertained that the interim government (i) effectively controls the country, 
(ii) generally recognizes the country’s international obligations, (iii) is willing and able to assume 
all  of  its  predecessor’s  obligations  to  ADB,  (iv)  can  ensure  the  continued  implementation  of 
ongoing projects and programs, and (v) has authorized a representative to make withdrawals. 
 
33. 
ADB  has  not  yet  proposed  a  resumption  of  formal  discussions  on  a  new  country 
partnership strategy or a new loan or TA. A proposal to resume full operations in the Fiji Islands 
will  be  made  once  there  is  evidence  that  the  conditions  for  that  second  stage  of  the 
reengagement  strategy  exist.  The  Pacific  Department  will  regularly  assess  the  conditions  for 
new  engagement.  Poverty  reduction  is  a  key  consideration  in  defining  new  lending  and 
nonlending priorities. FRUP III, on the other hand, is included in ADB’s approved and ongoing 
program, and it needs supplementary financing to reach completion. Its cost overruns were due 
to  factors  such  as  the  impact  of  rising  global  commodity  prices  that  were  largely  beyond  the 
control of the interim government. The significantly higher construction costs will use up the loan 
resources  before  the  Project  is  completed.  FRUP  III  is  estimated  to  be  about  75%  complete 
overall. If it is not completed the Project will not deliver its intended benefits to the poor, namely, 
regular  road  access  to  mainstream  markets  and  employment.  This  failure,  in  turn,  carries 
consequences  for  (i)  the  country,  in  terms  of  worsening  poverty;  and  (ii) ADB,  in  terms  of 
reputation risk associated with not reaching the desired development outputs and outcomes. As 
for the partially completed roads, significant areas (about 65% of the total length, or 33 km) will 
deteriorate, resulting in partial loss of the investment and increased costs of future upgrading to 
sealed highway standard.

Implementation Arrangements 

Executing Agency 

1. 
 
DNR9 will continue to be the EA for the proposed Project, with the permanent secretary 
36. 
of the Ministry of Works and Transport responsible for implementation. DNR’s existing FRUP III 
PMU,  staffed  by  a  project  management  engineer  and  a  qualified  accountant,  will  continue  to 
handle procurement and oversee the consulting services, under the supervision of the director 
of  roads  and  airfields.  The  performance  of  the  PMU  in  implementing  the  Project  under  the 
existing  sector  loan  has  been  satisfactory:  the  Project  (except  for  the  Kings  and  Lodoni 
Subproject) was completed by the end of 2005. However, a project procurement audit10 brought 
out  critical  deficiencies  in  documenting  project  expenditures,  particularly  for  force  account 
works.  The  audit  report  urged  the  EA  to  strengthen  the  PMU  for  future  ADB  project 
administration  and  management.  Improvements  were  made  after  the  audit,  including  the 
establishment  of  separate  financial  records  for  the  Project.  Such  financial  records  will 
substantiate the actual cost of completing the Project in a potential arbitration with the original 
contractor (para. 24). The EA has arranged for periodic external review of its records. The PMU 
will have a considerably lighter workload than it had until the end of 2005, when it administered 
several contracts, including those for road rehabilitation and consulting services. The remaining 
works  involve  only  two  contracts  and  one  force  account  section,  and  so  no  expansion  of  the 
PMU  staffing  is  required.  Contract  supervision  and  quality  control  will  be  carried  out  by 
experienced consultants in contract management roles (as defined in the civil works contracts), 
supported  by  a  technical  staff  (engineers,  surveyors,  materials  testing  technicians,  and  works 
inspectors) to be provided directly by the EA.

Advance Action and Retroactive Financing 

5. 
 
41. 
Continuity  of  the  physical  work  is  critical  to  completing  the  subproject  in  a  reasonable 
period of time. ADB financing for ongoing contracts will be used up in the fourth quarter of 2008. 
The Government has asked ADB to approve advance action for the procurement of civil works. 
Advance  action  covers  invitation  of  bids,  bidding,  bid  evaluation,  and  contract  award.  The 
advance  action  will  be  reviewed  for  conformity  to  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines.  The 
Government has been advised that approval of the advance action, if granted, does not commit 
ADB to provide supplementary financing for the Project. 
 
42. 
The Project will provide retroactive financing for civil works. Retroactive financing will be 
permitted  only  if  (i)  ADB  and  the  Borrower  specifically  agree  to  it  in  the  loan  agreement,  and 
only  under  the  terms  of  the  relevant  agreement;  (ii)  the  works  for  which  it  is  requested  are 
procured according to ADB’s Procurement Guidelines; and (iii) not more than 20% of the loan 
amount  is  financed  retroactively.  The  expenditures  must  have  been  incurred  before  the  loan 
agreement takes effect, but no earlier than 12 months before the date the agreement is signed. 
 
43. 
The  Government  has  informed  ADB  that  it  applied  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  in 
obtaining  bids  for  the  remaining  two  civil  works  contract  packages,  including  advertising  of 
tenders  on  ADB’s  website.  Procurement  followed  single-stage,  one-envelope  international 
bidding with post-qualification. The Government will submit its bid evaluation reports, including a 
full  account  of  the  procurement  process,  to  ADB  for  review  before  any  contract  award.  The 
procurement plan is in Appendix 5.

Monitoring and Evaluation 

8. 
 
47. 
The  Government  has  compiled  and  analyzed  base  data  to  facilitate  benefit  monitoring 
and evaluation of the Project’s socioeconomic impact. The monitoring and evaluation program 
comprises three major activities: (i) benchmarking, to assist project planners and implementers 
in designing and implementing projects that respond to the needs of the intended beneficiaries, 
and to provide a basis for an objective assessment of the impact of the Project; (ii) monitoring 
during implementation to ensure that the Project indeed benefits the intended beneficiaries; and 
(iii) evaluation  after  the  Project  to  assess  its  overall  effectiveness.  Such  monitoring  and 
evaluation  has  been  done  for  the  completed  subprojects  and  is  ongoing  for  the  Kings  and 
Lodoni roads subproject. Measurement indicators under the original Project are in Appendix 6.

Anticorruption Policy  

 
48. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  Government  and  the  EA.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good  governance, 
accountability,  and  transparency,  ADB  reserves  the  right  to  investigate,  directly  or  through  its 
agents,  any  alleged  corrupt, fraudulent,  collusive,  or  coercive  practices  relating to the  Project. 
To support these efforts, relevant provisions of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy are included in the 
loan regulations and the bidding documents for the Project. In particular, all contracts financed 
by  ADB  in  connection  with  the  Project  shall  include  provisions  specifying  the  right  of  ADB  to 
audit  and  examine  the  records  and  accounts  of  the  EA  and  all  contractors,  suppliers, 
consultants,  and  other  service  providers  as  they  relate  to  the  Project.  The  Project  will  also 
comply  with  all  applicable  anticorruption  laws  of  the  Republic  of  the  Fiji  Islands.  A  project 
website will be established and used to disclose the audited project financial accounts, project 
progress, and procurement activities.

 Project Review

49. 
ADB and the Government will undertake semiannual and midterm reviews of the Project 
to assess (i) compliance with the loan covenants, (ii) physical achievements against milestones, 
(iii) loan disbursements and financial progress, and (iv) project implementation issues that need 
to  be  resolved  or  acted  on.  The  EA  will  review  the  estimates  of  the  subproject  costs  each 
quarter and reassess the project benefits if such costs increase by more than 10% of the base 
costs. Assumptions and risks noted in the design and monitoring framework will be periodically 
reviewed and corrective action taken if needed. 
 
 

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACT, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

 
A. 

Economic Analysis 

50. 
The  subproject  is  part  of  the  Government’s  FRUP  Ill  and  supports  its  macroeconomic 
and  sector  objectives.  To  ensure  the  economic  viability  of  all  subprojects  eligible  for  ADB 
financing,  the  minimum economic  internal  rate  of  return  was  set  at  12%.  The  benefits  of  road 
upgrading  will  accrue  primarily  from  savings  in  vehicle  operating  costs.  Daily  traffic  on  each 
subproject road was forecast in the feasibility documentation. From experience with earlier road 
upgrading  projects  in  Fiji  Islands,  traffic  on  upgraded  road  links  has  increased  beyond  the 
forecasts. Other benefits include lower transport costs both to suppliers and to users of goods 
and  services;  increased  agricultural  production  resulting  from  improved  access  to  rural 
communities and market centers; better access to health services, jobs, and schools; reduced 
dust;  and  increased  tourism.  Besides  the  benefits  from  road  use,  the  civil  works  under  the 
Project  have  generated  at  least  4,000–5,000  person-years  of  employment  for  skilled  and 
unskilled  labor.  The  partly  completed  roads  will  deteriorate  if  they  are  not  completed  or  if 
completion is deferred. The deterioration will result in increased maintenance costs and loss of 
benefits from sunk costs. 
 
51. 
The subproject was previously investigated under feasibility studies carried out for FRUP 
III  in  1997–1998  under  preparatory  TA.  The  present  review  of  the  economic  analysis  uses 
methods similar to those used in the FRUP III feasibility study, with updated traffic projections 
and  cost base.  But  instead of  the  Transport  Research Laboratory  Road  Transport  Investment 
Model  as  the  tool  of  analysis,  this  review  uses  the  World  Bank  Highway  Development  and 
Management Model and updates the base case to take account of the work done in the interim. 
Also, the present analysis is incremental, so it considers only those construction costs that are 
not already sunk, and those benefits obtained from upgrading the road from its partly completed 
state to its final design standard. 
 
Economic  costs,  derived  from  financial  costs,  include  construction,  operation,  and 
52. 
maintenance costs and exclude price contingencies, taxes, duties, subsidies, and royalties.11 A 
standard conversion factor of 0.986 was used to revalue goods and services at world prices into 
national currency, and a shadow wage rate factor of 0.86 was applied to local unskilled labor. 
These same factors were applied to capital and maintenance costs and the elements of vehicle 
operating and passenger time costs. For minor items where assessing the proportion of tax and 
duty within the financial costs was difficult, a conversion factor of 0.80 was applied. The project 
roads  are  expected  to  have  an  economic  life  of  20–25  years  before  major  pavement 
rehabilitation  is  needed,  with  resurfacing  at  intervals  throughout  this  period.  The  incremental 

                                                
11 Royalties refer to payments to landowners for gravel and soil extracted from quarries and pits on their land. 

 

13 

 

 operation and maintenance costs are the difference between the maintenance requirements for 
the proposed upgraded bitumen-sealed roads and the maintenance requirements of the existing 
gravel-surface roads. 
 
To estimate the benefits to road users, the differences between road user costs with and 
53. 
without  the  Project  were  compared.  Quantified  road  user  benefits  comprise  vehicle  operating 
cost and journey time savings, and reductions in traffic delay and associated vehicle operating 
costs at one-lane bridges. Producer surplus benefits were included for agricultural development 
stimulated by the subproject within the direct area of influence of the road. Road user savings 
were not included for agricultural freight traffic to avoid double-counting. The producer surplus 
benefits were derived from detailed analysis from the original FRUP III feasibility study, updated 
to reflect changes in the cost base from 1997 to 2008. 
 
54. 
Unit  cost  data  for  vehicle  replacement,  tires,  fuel,  oil,  maintenance  labor,  and  crew 
wages came from road feasibility studies done in 2005 and 2007 for the Department of National 
Roads and ADB for the proposed FRUP IV. These studies included comprehensive surveys of 
vehicle operating cost inputs, market prices, taxes, and duties. Apart from fuel, vehicle running 
costs were updated through the use of the “all groups” and “transport group” components of the 
consumer  price  index  as  reported  by  the  Reserve  Bank  of  Fiji  Islands  and  the  Fiji  Islands 
Bureau of Statistics. In the case of the transport group index, increases since 2007 are almost 
entirely  attributable  to  gasoline  and  diesel  fuel;  the  economic  cost  of  fuel  was  therefore 
reassessed through the use of current retail prices, without taking duties and taxes into account. 
Fuel  costs  are  volatile,  but  the  present  level  is  judged  to  be  suitably  representative  of  the 
medium-term outlook, and corresponds to a light crude oil price of around US$120 per barrel. 
Fuel, a significant component of road user costs, has more than doubled in economic cost since 
the original FRUP III feasibility study was prepared. 
 
55. 
Sensitivity testing  was applied  to  the  EIRR  against  construction  cost,  base  traffic  level, 
and traffic growth rate, including or excluding producer surplus and economic multiplier benefits. 
The  value  needed  to give an  EIRR of  12%  (the switching  value) and  the  sensitivity  index  (the 
percentage change in the variable divided by the percentage change in the net present value) 
were  calculated  in  each  case.  Numerical  simulation  techniques  were  used  to  model  the 
probability  that  the  EIRR  would  exceed  12%,  given  the  maximum,  most  likely,  and  minimum 
values of the main input parameters and assumed probability distributions. 
 
56. 
As in the original analysis, no allowance was made for changes in accident costs. While 
the  improved  alignment  and  road  surface  are  potential  safety  improvement  factors,  increased 
traffic  speeds  may  lead  to  crash  injuries  that  could  be  more  severe,  depending  on  the 
effectiveness  of  traffic  management,  particularly  through  or  close  to  villages,  signage,  and 
policing. A summary economic analysis for the subproject is in Appendix 7. 
 

1. 

Kings Road 

57. 
Kings Road is expected to yield benefits that other roads considered for the Project will 
not offer. These are due to a reduction in length of almost 5 km, representing a distance saving 
of over 9% of the existing length, and benefits to diverted traffic. The benefits to diverted traffic 
were  calculated  from  the  results  of  origin  and  destination  surveys  that  estimated  the  traffic 
diverting to Kings Road from other routes, and from savings accruing from the reduced journey 
length.  The  calculation  of  vehicle  operating  cost  savings  was  based  on  economic  costs  per 
kilometer, on the assumption that the journeys would be made on a good sealed road in both 
the with- and the without-project cases. 

14 

 

 

 Traffic growth in recent years on the Kings Road project section has been very variable, 
58. 
averaging 8% on  the first  link  between  Korovou and Waito,  but erratic on  the  other  links.  The 
progressive  upgrading  of  adjacent  sections  of  the  road  has  influenced  traffic  growth  on  the 
project links. The section north of Nayavu has been upgraded since 2004, and this has probably 
contributed to strong growth between 2004 and 2008. More generally across the country, traffic 
growth  rates, averaged  over  175  of  DNR’s  traffic  counts  between  2000  and  2004,  showed  an 
increase  of 25%  (4.5%  per  year)  compared  with an  increase  of 14.6%  in  real gross domestic 
product (GDP) (3.5% per year), for an implied factor of 1.72. 
 
59. 
The  original  FRUP  III  feasibility  study  established  the  traffic  generation  effects  of 
upgrading  sections  of  Kings  Road  from  gravel  to  seal.  Traffic  increases  after  completion 
measured at  six  sites  were  observed  to vary from  28% to 92%,  with a general  relationship of 
50% growth for light traffic and 5% for heavy traffic for road lengths of over 10 km. The evidence 
is  still  valid  and  in  some  respects  may  be  a  conservative  estimate,  as  the  subproject  will 
complete the sealing of Kings Road. In particular, it is not possible to distinguish between heavy 
and light vehicles in generated traffic growth: both respond strongly to upgrading. A 50% growth 
rate for normal traffic after implementation was therefore used. 
 
60. 
The estimated  traffic did not  allow for possible  increases  caused by an acceleration  of 
development  in  the  northeast  of  Fiji  Islands,  which  may  follow  the  upgrading  of  Kings  Road. 
Another  source  of  additional  benefit  that  was  not  included  in  the  analysis  is  the  removal  of 
constraints  on  traffic  caused  by  the  closure  of  the  road  in  the  rainy  season.  Bridgeworks, 
already completed under the subproject, will prevent such closures. 
 
An evaluation period of 25 years, covering the 2-year construction period and the design 
61. 
life  of  the  road  before  major  rehabilitation,  was  used  in  the  analysis.  The  diverted  traffic  and 
producer surplus benefits were estimated for the Kings Road link as a whole, and were added to 
the benefits to normal and generated traffic calculated for each link through the use of the World 
Bank’s  Highway  Development  and  Management  (HDM)  model.12 The  incremental  analysis  to 
project completion resulted in a present value of F$49.5 million for discounted costs and F$50.3 
million for discounted benefits, and an EIRR of 12.2%. 
 
An  analysis  of  risk  using  numerical  simulation  in which  the  main  sensitivity  parameters 
62. 
were replaced with defined probability distributions was carried out. On this basis, there is 54% 
probability that the EIRR for the subproject will exceed 12%, and 94% probability that the EIRR 
will exceed 10%. 
 
63. 
The  original  feasibility  study,  on  the  other  hand,  yielded  an  EIRR  of  15.7%,  and  a 
present value of F$16.8 million for discounted costs and F$23.0 million for discounted benefits. 
The  EIRR  for  the  completion  of  the  subproject  still  just  exceeds  12%  despite  the  greatly 
increased  cost  for  the  following  reasons:  (i)  base  traffic  has  grown  substantially  from  230 
vehicles  per  day  in  1997  to  540  vehicles  per  day  in  2008,  averaged  over  the  length  of  the 
subproject;  (ii)  the  traffic  that  can  be  diverted  has  also  grown;  (iii)  while  some  savings  in 
distance reduction and single-lane bridge replacement have already been achieved, most of the 
user  benefits  will  arise  from  the  pavement  construction  and  sealing,  which  is  yet  to  be 
completed;  and  (iv) while  construction  costs  have  increased,  so  too  have  the  unit  values  of 
project  benefits.  A  post-evaluation  of  the  total  costs  and  benefits  of  the  subproject,  including 
sunk  costs  and  benefits  compared  against  the  pre-construction  condition,  is  likely  to  show  a

15 

 

 lower EIRR. However, it is the incremental costs and benefits to completion that are relevant to 
the supplementary-funding decision. 

Lodoni Road 

 
2. 
 
64. 
Traffic  volumes  on  Lodoni  Road  are  influenced  by  the  ferry  services  operating  from 
Natovi Jetty. When the FRUP III feasibility study was prepared, there were daily return services 
to Ovalau (Buresala) and Nabouwalu, and a single weekly service to Savusavu, all operated by 
Patterson Brothers Shipping. At that time, ferry services were estimated to contribute about 40 
heavy trucks per day. Patterson Brothers continues to operate a daily service to Savusavu, and 
has  had  disputes  with  other  operators  regarding  berth  occupancy  at  Natovi,  a  public  facility, 
indicating  that  there  will  be  continued  strong  demand  for  its  use  as  a  boarding  point  for 
interisland  services.  The  completion  of  a  sealed  road  connection  is  likely  to  make  the  facility 
even  more  attractive.  Lodoni  Road  also  serves  two  major  educational  establishments,  the 
Queen Victoria School and the Ratu Kadalevu School, in addition to the entire population of the 
east coast of Viti Levu north of Korovou. 
 
65. 
Traffic  growth  over  2000–2004  on  Lodoni  Road  averaged  about  6.5%  (linear)  at  both 
DNR traffic count sites. However, a comparison against the 1995 counts indicates that this may 
be  a  statistical  aberration. A normal  traffic growth  rate  of 3.5% over  the  medium  to  long term, 
similar to that adopted for Kings Road, was therefore used in the analysis. As with Kings Road, 
and following an analysis of previous projects in the area, generated traffic was assumed to be 
50%. 
 
A present value of F$12.5 million for discounted costs and F$15.6 million for discounted 
66. 
benefits for the completion of the Lodoni Road upgrading, and incremental EIRR of 15.2%, was 
derived. The risk analysis shows 89% probability that the EIRR for the completion of the Project 
will exceed 12%, and 99% probability that it will exceed 10%. 
 
67. 
In comparison, the original feasibility study gave an EIRR of 14.8%, with a present value 
of  F$10.0  million  for  discounted  costs  and  F$12.4  million  for  discounted  benefits.  The 
incremental  EIRR  is  still  greater  than  12%  despite  the  increased  subproject  cost  for  reasons 
similar  to  those  for  Kings  Road,  although  in  this  case  there  is  no  diverted  traffic  and  a 
much-smaller reduction in road length.

Confirmation of Economic Viability 

Environmental Impact 

68.  When  the  incremental  benefits and  costs of  completing each  road  are  compared,  both 
links remain economically viable, with an EIRR of 12.2% for Kings Road and 15.2% for Lodoni 
Road. The combined EIRR for the entire Project is 12.8%. 
 
B. 
 
69. 
The  original  contractor  for  the  Kings  and  Lodoni  roads  was  required  to  prepare  an 
environmental  management  plan  (EMP)  for  the  construction  of  the  works.  In  addition, 
environmental impact assessments (EIAs) and associated EMPs were required for all quarries 
or  borrow  pits  from  which  more  than  5,000  cubic  meters  of  soil,  gravel,  or  rock  were  to  be 
extracted.  These  EMPs  and  EIAs  were  prepared  and  approved  by  the  supervising  engineers 
and by the Ministry of Tourism and Environment, and the work has conformed to the subproject 
EMPs.  About  80%  of  the  site  has  been  worked  on,  with  earthworks  completed  within  the  site 
boundaries.  Existing  quarries  (those  for  which  EIAs  were  prepared  by  the  original  contractor)

will  be  used  to  complete  the  works;  no  new  borrow  pits  of  significance  are  expected.  In  fact, 
unused  borrow  pits  have  been  satisfactorily  reinstated,  as  was  noted  during  the  Fact-Finding 
Mission. 
 
Bidding documents for contract packages awarded for the completion of the subproject 
70. 
after  the  termination  of  the  original  contract  require  the  contractors  to  adhere  to  approved

C. 
 
71. 
A social impact study of the subproject (Supplementary Appendix A) confirmed that the 
subproject  roads  serve  a  predominantly  rural  and  relatively  disadvantaged  segment  of  the 
community. In 2002, the incidence of poverty was significantly higher in the area served directly 
by  the  roads  (76.4%  of  the  sample  group)  than  in  rural  areas  nationwide  (40%).13 That  same 
year, the incidence of poverty (84%) was considerably higher among Fijians in the study area 
(84%)  than  among  Fijians  nationwide  (34%).  In  contrast,  the  incidence  of  poverty  was  less 
among  the  Indo-Fijian  sample  group  (22%)  than  among  Indo-Fijians  nationwide  (37%). 
Furthermore,  90%  of  the  Fijian  sample  group  had  household  incomes  in  2002  that  were  well 
below  the  national  average 14  for  rural  Fijian  households  ($11,082),  while  only  22%  of  the 
Indo-Fijian  sample  group  was  living  well  below  the  national  average  for  rural  Indo-Fijians 
($9,653).  The  subproject  will  reduce  vehicle  operating  costs  and  produce  time  savings  (direct 
benefits), and will also improve access to rural communities and to basic social facilities, as well 
as socioeconomic conditions in the areas served by the upgraded roads (indirect benefits). 
 
D. 
 
72. 
All  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  actions  needed  for  the  subproject  have  been 
completed  satisfactorily  according  to  the  provisions  of  the  original  loan  agreement,  the 
Government’s policy and procedures, and ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995). 
 
E. 
 
73. 
No  gender  issues  or  specific  opportunities  for  gender  equality  are  associated  with  the 
completion  of  the  Kings  and  Lodoni  roads,  given  the  limited  focus  of  the  subproject  on  road 
construction.  But  the  Project  as  a  whole  will  have  pervasive  benefits:  all  segments  of  the 
population—women, men, youth, and disadvantaged groups—will gain from it. 
 
F. 
 
The  disengagement of  the  consulting firm that  was  supervising  the  subproject brings a 
74. 
risk that alternative arrangements will not be satisfactory, since the EA seems to have replaced 
the consultant solely to save on costs. The quality of the work, in a difficult environment of poor 
soils  and  high  rainfall,  requires a  comprehensive  system  of  inspection and  testing,  but  such a 
system  may  not hold up  if  those  responsible are  not  independent  of  the EA  and are  not  held 
accountable for failing to perform adequately. Kings Road in particular is in a high-rainfall area,

 and poor climatic conditions during implementation could delay its completion. Hiring individual

75. 
The Government has been slow in arranging a variation to the contract for the provision 
of pavement materials. Base-course material must be washed to remove clay contaminants so 
that it meets the specified quality; the potential need for such washing (at additional cost to the 
Government)  was  foreseen  in  the  contract.  Delays  in  resolving  this  issue  will  directly  affect 
subsequent work, as the material is needed for the final pavement layer before the bituminous 
seal  can  be  applied.  This  is  an  immediate  requirement  in  one  of  the  contracts  still  to  be 
procured. Deferring the award of this contract until there is enough supply of base course may 
mitigate  this  risk.  However,  deferment  will  also  increase  the  risk  of  damage  to  the  underlying 
pavement layers that have already been constructed. The EA has advised that the bids received 
so  far  are  either  heavily  qualified  (to  the  extent  of  being  unresponsive)  or  submitted  by 
unqualified  bidders.  The  earliest  at  which  this  contract  can  be  awarded,  after  new  bids  are 
invited, is April 2009, giving the EA more time to resolve the issue of base-course supply. Base 
course will not be needed for the second contract until August 2009, if the contract is awarded 
by January 2009. The issue preventing agreement is financial rather than technical. Risks lie in 
the  possibility  that  negotiations  will  continue  to  be  protracted.  An  agreement  for  mediation  or 
arbitration on the cost of the additional work would allow it to begin immediately, with costs to be 
determined on the basis of actual costs. 
 
76. 
Two ICB contracts still have to be awarded, and the cost of all work, including the force 
account work, is very sensitive to the price of fuel in particular. The cost estimates are based on 
bid prices  received  in  mid-2008,  and  these  were in  turn  based on  high fuel  costs,  which  have 
since moderated significantly. Actual fuel costs will be reflected in the final contract price of one 
of the ICB contracts (if awarded under the current bid process) through its contractual provisions 
for price adjustment. The other ICB contract has no price adjustment provision because it is of 
relatively  short  duration  (13  months).  The  latter  contract  may  be  rebid  with  price  adjustment 
provisions.  The  former  contract  may  also  be  rebid  to  ensure  that  the  bid  prices  adequately 
reflect  the  significant  economic  changes  that  have  occurred  worldwide  since  July  2008 
(including currency realignments and a significant fall in the price of oil). 
 
The timely completion of the subproject depends on the careful selection of appropriately 
77. 
experienced and competent contractors to do the work. The original contractor failed to provide 
adequate skilled supervisory personnel or sufficient equipment for the work, with due regard to 
the  production  rates  required  and  the  limitations  imposed  by  the  generally  wet  climatic 
conditions  in  the  area.  A  thorough  review  of  the  bidders’  experience  in  similar  work,  and  the 
amount, age, and condition of the equipment that is proposed for the work, should therefore be 
part  of  the  bid  evaluation.  The  EA  should  require  a  firm  undertaking  from  the  recommended 
contractor that it will mobilize at least the promised level of resources. 
 
78. 
The completion of the subproject is subject to technical risks that are largely within the 
control of the EA. These risks can be satisfactorily mitigated through sound project management 
and supervision.

(viii)  Labor standards. DNR will ensure that provisions are stipulated in all civil works 
contracts  to  require  contractors  employed  under  the  Project  to  incorporate 
minimum  workplace  occupational  safety  norms,  including  the  core  labor 
standards  as  identified  in  the  fundamental  International  Labour  Organization 
conventions.  DNR  will  ensure  that  civil  works  contractors  comply  with  all 
applicable  labor  laws  and  do  not  employ  child  labor  in  any  aspect  of  their 
activities.  DNR  will  ensure  that  contractors  provide  appropriate  training,  and 
information  materials  for  workers  on  HIV/AIDS  prevention,  and  that  contractors 
and their workers observe local protocols concerning acceptable behavior toward 
the  local  population.  DNR  will  require  contractors  not  to  differentiate  wages 
between men and women for work of equal value. All civil works contracts to be 
financed  under  the  ADB  loan  will  include  specific  clauses  to  this  effect,  and 
compliance shall be strictly monitored during project implementation. 

(ix) 

Governance  and  anticorruption.  The  Government  will  ensure  that  (a)  the 
Project  is  carried  out  in  accordance  with  all  applicable  anticorruption  laws  and 
regulations in the Fiji Islands and ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended 
to date); and (b) a project website is developed within 2 months of effectiveness 
of  the  loan  agreement,  and  maintained  to  disclose  the  audited  project  financial 
accounts, project progress, and procurement activities. 

 
Condition for Disbursement 

B. 
 
80. 
No  disbursement  of  the  loan  proceeds  for  works  will  take  place  until  DNR  will  have 
recruited  consultants  with  competence  and  experience  acceptable  to  ADB,  for  construction 
supervision,  including  supervision  of  the  works  procured  by  force  account.  The  following 
full-time  positions  will  be  occupied  by  the  consultants:  a  supervising  engineer,  a  resident 
engineer, a materials engineer, and a senior works inspector. 
 
 

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

 
81. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  supplementary 
loan of US$36,100,000 to the Republic of the Fiji Islands for the Third Road Upgrading (Sector) 
Project from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance with 
ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility;  a  term  of  20  years, 
including a grace period of 2 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft Loan Agreement presented to the Board.

Appendix 7 

A. 

Introduction 

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 

Subproject.  For  the  Lodoni  and  Kings  Road  upgrading  subproject,  the  without-project 
1. 
base  case  against  which  changes  in  road  provider  and  road  user  costs  are  compared  is  the 
partially  upgraded  gravel-standard  road  on  a  constrained  alignment.  The  with-project  case 
involves  carriageway  widening,  double  surface-treated  bitumen  chip-seal  pavement,  minor 
horizontal  realignment  with  some  length  reduction,  improvements  in  the  vertical  profile,  and 
replacement of single-lane bridges in poor structural condition with two-lane bridges. 
 
2. 
Previous  Investigation.  The  subproject  was  previously  investigated  under  feasibility 
studies  carried  out  for  Third  Road  Upgrading  (Sector)  Project  (FRUP  III)  in  1997–1998  as 
preparatory  technical  assistance.1 These  studies  should  be  referred  to  for  details  of  the  prior 
economic  analysis.  The  Kings  Road  section  (Korovou–Dama)  was  originally  investigated  in 
1995 as  a  possible subproject for  the earlier  FRUP  II,  but  the  matter  was not pursued  at  that 
time. 
 
3. 
The  prior  economic  analysis  estimated  discounted  economic  costs,  benefits,  and 
economic internal rate of return (EIRR), as shown in Table A7.1 below. Vehicle operating cost 
and travel time savings were evaluated in the usual way for normal, generated, and, in the case 
of Kings Road, diverted traffic. For agricultural freight traffic, a producer surplus approach was 
used for Kings Road, in view of the Subproject’s function in enabling cash crop production from 
the hinterland served. The cash cropping of perishable market produce, sensitive to time delay 
and  road  roughness,  is  now  constrained  by  lack  of  reliable  all-weather  access.  The  price 
structure, supply elasticities, and potential production volumes were estimated through the use 
of  Ministry  of  Agriculture  data  for  fruit  and  vegetable  crops,  but  excluding  the  area  already 
earmarked for a government development project.

Appendix 7 

 
31 

Current Review. This review of the economic analysis uses methodology similar to that 
4. 
used  in  the  FRUP  III  feasibility  study  but  with  updated  traffic  projections  and  cost  base. 
Differences lie in the use of the World Bank Highway Development and Management (HDM) in 
place of  the  Transport  Research  Laboratory  Road  Transport  Investment  Model  (RTIM)  as  the 
analysis tool, and the updating of the base case to take account of the work already done in the 
interim  on  the  first  section  of  Kings  Road.  The  analysis  is  made  on  an  incremental  basis, 
comparing  the  economic  benefits  yet  to be obtained  by  completing  the  subproject  against the 
incremental  costs  to  completion  of  construction.  Costs  already  expended  in  the  partial 
construction  to  date  are  regarded  as  sunk,  and  so  are  not  included  in  the  analysis.  Similarly, 
benefits already obtained, such as through route shortening on the first section of Kings Road 
and completion of several single-lane bridges, are excluded from the analysis. 
 
Costs.  Economic  costs  were  derived  from  financial  costs  and  include  the  cost  of 
5. 
construction,  operation,  and  maintenance.  Price  contingencies,  taxes,  duties,  subsidies,  and 
royalties  are  excluded.  As  with  other  recent  ADB  projects  in  the  Fiji  Islands,  a  standard 
conversion factor of 0.986 was used to revalue goods and services at world prices into national 
currency  and  a  shadow  wage  rate  factor  of  0.86  was  applied  to  local  unskilled  labor.  These 
same  factors  were  applied  to  capital  and  maintenance  costs  and  the  elements  of  vehicle 
operating  and  passenger  time  costs.  A  conversion  factor  of  0.80  was  applied  to  minor  items 
where  assessing  the  proportion  of  tax  and  duty  within  the  financial  costs  was  difficult.  The 
project  roads  are  expected  to  have  an  economic  life  of  20–25  years  before  major  pavement 
rehabilitation,  with  resurfacing  applied  at  intervals  throughout  this  period.  The  incremental 
operation and maintenance costs are the difference between the maintenance requirements for 
the proposed upgraded bitumen-sealed roads and the maintenance requirements of the existing 
gravel-surface roads. 
 
6. 
Benefits.  The  benefits  to  road  users  were  estimated  by  comparing  the  differences 
between road user costs for the with- and without-project cases. Quantified road user benefits 
comprise  vehicle  operating  cost  and  journey  time  savings,  and  reductions  in  traffic  delay  and 
associated  vehicle  operating  costs  at  one-lane  bridges.  Producer  surplus  benefits  have  been 
included  for  agricultural  development  stimulated  by  the  subproject  within  the  direct  area  of 
influence of the road. Road user savings have not been included for agricultural freight traffic to 
avoid  double-counting.  The producer  surplus  benefits are  based on detailed analysis from  the 
original FRUP III feasibility study, updated to reflect changes in the cost base between 1997 and 
2008. 
 
Modeling.  The  HDM  model  was  used  to  compare  the  annual  streams  of  economic 
7. 
capital and operating costs and benefits and derived net present values (NPVs) and EIRR. All 
costs  and  benefits  are  expressed  in  2008  constant  prices.  The  analysis  period  was  25  years 
from 2009 to 2033, extending over a 2-year construction program and the economic life of the 
upgraded  road  links  before  major  rehabilitation.  Diverted  traffic  benefits  and  producer  surplus 
benefits were estimated exogenously to the HDM model. 
 
8. 
Sensitivity  and  Risk.  Sensitivity  testing  was  applied  to  the  EIRR  against  a  20% 
increase  in  construction  cost,  a  20%  decrease  in  base  traffic  level,  a  one-percentage-point 
reduction  in  normal  traffic  growth  rate,  a  crude  oil  price  reduction  of  25%,  the  exclusion  of 
producer surplus benefits, and a project completion delay of 1 year. The value needed to give 
an  EIRR  of 12%  (the  switching  value)  and  the  sensitivity  index  (the  percentage  change  in  the 
variable divided by the percentage change in the NPV) were calculated in each case. Numerical 
simulation techniques were used to model the probability that the EIRR would exceed 12% and

B. 

Road User Costs 

10%, given the  maximum,  most  likely,  and  minimum  values of  the  main  input parameters  and 
assumed probability distributions. 

9. 
Unit  cost  data  for  vehicle  replacement,  tires,  fuel,  oil,  maintenance  labor,  and  crew 
wages  have  been  derived  from  road  feasibility  studies  carried  out  in  2005  and  2007  for  the 
Department  of  National  Roads  (DNR)  and  ADB  for  the  proposed  FRUP  IV.  These  studies 
included  comprehensive  surveys  of  vehicle  operating  cost  inputs,  market  prices,  taxes,  and 
duties.  Apart  from  fuel,  vehicle  running  costs  have  been  updated  using  the  “all  groups”  and 
“transport group” components of the consumer price index as reported by the Reserve Bank of 
Fiji and the Fiji Islands Bureau of Statistics. In the case of the transport group index, increases 
since 2007 are almost entirely attributable to gasoline and diesel fuel, and the economic cost of 
fuel has therefore been reassessed using current retail prices and removing duties and taxes. 
Fuel  costs  are  volatile,  but  the  present  level  is  judged  to  be  suitably  representative  of  the 
medium-term  outlook,  and  corresponds  to  a  light  crude  oil  price  in  the  region  of  US$120  per 
barrel. Fuel forms a significant component of road user costs and its economic cost has more 
than doubled since the original FRUP III feasibility study was prepared. 
 
Values  for  work  travel  time,  crew  wages,  and  maintenance  labor  are  based  on  2007 
10. 
surveyed values used in prior feasibility studies carried out for the DNR. Although wage growth 
expectations  as  reported  by  the  Reserve  Bank  of  Fiji,  average  3%  per  year,  in  the  present 
economic climate no increment from 2007 has been assumed. 
 
11. 
As  with  the  original  analysis,  no  allowance  has  been  made  for  changes  in  accident 
costs. While the improved alignment and road surface are potential safety improvement factors, 
increased  traffic  speeds  may  lead  to  more  severe  crash  injuries.  The outcome  will  depend on 
the  effectiveness  of  traffic  management,  particularly  through or  close  to  villages,  signage, and 
policing. 

C. 

Kings Road, Korovou–Nayavu 

1. 

Road Links for Analysis 

12. 
The study section of Kings Road begins at the roundabout immediately north of Korovou 
at the junction with Lodoni Road, identified as Road 23000, kilometer (km) 10.108, in the DNR’s 
asset  management  inventory.  It ends  at  the  DNR  depot  in  Nayavu,  identified as  km  32.864  in 
the inventory (note: inventory kilometer points may not correspond to actual distances because 
construction  changes  route  length  over  time).  The  road  has  been  divided  into  three  links  for 
analysis in relation to changes in traffic level, road alignment, and terrain: (i) the first 9.2 km to 
Waito,  which  is  mainly  level  to  rolling  terrain  through  agricultural  land  used  for  dairy  farming; 
(ii) a mountainous 11.4 km section, where the road rises over a range of hills before descending 
to the Wainibuka Valley, the end of the  section being at Waioluta,  the  junction  with Vunidawa 
Road;  and  (iii)  the  remaining  11.2  km,  which  follows  the  east  bank  of  the  Wainibuka  River 
through numerous villages, some of which are bypassed by the new road alignment.

4. 

Traffic Growth and Projections 

17. 
Traffic  is  considered  in  the three  categories  of  normal  traffic  growth  (traffic  growth that 
would  occur  irrespective of  the Project), generated traffic  (new  traffic developed as a  result  of 
increased activity attributable to the Project, and diverted traffic (rerouting of traffic induced by 
the Project). 
 
18. 
Normal  Traffic. Traffic growth over recent years on the Kings Road subproject section 
has been very variable, averaging 8% on the first link between Korovou and Waito, but erratic 
on  the  remaining  links.  Progressive  upgrading  of  adjacent  sections  of  Kings  Road  has 
influenced  traffic growth on  the project  links.  The  section north of  Nayavu has  been upgraded 
since  2004,  and  is  credited  with  the  strong  growth  between  2004  and  2008.  More  generally 
across  the  country,  traffic  growth  rates,  averaged  over  175  of  DNR’s  traffic  counts  between 
2000 and 2004, showed an increase of 25% (4.5% yearly), compared with an increase of 14.6% 
in real gross domestic product (GDP) (3.5% yearly), an implied factor of 1.72. Over the longer 
term from 1992, traffic growth on interurban routes has averaged around 4.0%–4.5% per year. 
While  GDP has  been flat  since  2005, the  Reserve  Bank of  Fiji  expects an upward path  to  be 
regained by 2010. Historic performance indicates linear rather than compound growth, and the 
medium- to long-term growth in GDP is estimated to be 2%, and interurban normal traffic growth 
3.5%  (linear).  The  HDM  model  requires  the  use  of  compound  growth  rates,  which  can  be 
approximated by providing for 3.5% growth to 2018 and 3% thereafter. 
 
19. 
Generated  Traffic.  The  original  FRUP  III  feasibility  study  established  the  traffic 
generation  effects  of  upgrading  sections  of  Kings  Road  from  gravel  to  seal.  Traffic  increases 
after  completion  measured  at  six  sites  varied from  28% to  92%,  with a general  relationship of 
50% growth for light traffic and 5% for heavy traffic for road lengths over 10 km. The evidence is 
still valid and in some respects may be a conservative estimate, as the Subproject will provide 
the  missing  link  to  complete  the  sealing  of  Kings  Road.  In  particular,  it  is  not  possible  to 
distinguish between heavy and light vehicles in generated traffic growth: both respond strongly 
to  upgrading.  A 50%  rate  of growth  in  normal  traffic  levels  after  implementation has  therefore 
been  used.  Agricultural  development  traffic,  the  economic  benefits  of  which  are  evaluated 
through the producer surplus approach, is additional to this generated traffic.  
 
Diverted  Traffic.  Traffic  levels  on  Kings  Road,  measured  at  Vunidawa  Junction,  have 
20. 
varied  between  100  vpd  and  200  vpd  as  far  back  as  the  1970s.  Traffic  has  increased  and 
decreased  in  response  to  economic  conditions and  to the  comparative attractiveness of  Kings 

 

  

Appendix 7 

 
35 

Road  and  Queens  Road  as  possible  alternative  routes  for  longer-distance  traffic.  As  Queens 
Road was upgraded in the 1980s, historic traffic counts suggest that some 60–80 vpd diverted 
away from Kings Road. This indicates the potential, once Kings Road is upgraded to a sealed 
standard over its full length, for a diversion of traffic back to Kings Road for those trips, mainly 
with one end in Suva, and destination in the north and northeast of Viti Levu. 
 
21. 
The attraction back to Kings Road will come from reduced travel times, distance savings 
on the upgraded road, lower vehicle operating costs, and the inherent attractiveness of a sealed 
route  over  a  gravel  road  particularly  for  light  traffic,  because  of  higher  trip  reliability  and  the 
absence  of  loose  gravel  and  dust,  which  are  known  drawbacks  for  road  users,  even  if  not 
routinely quantified in monetary benefits. Indeed, sealing the last section, which the subproject 
will  achieve,  is  likely  to  give  a  once-off  increase  in  traffic  specifically  by  making  the  route 
acceptable  for  two-wheel  drive  vehicles.  The  original  FRUP  III  feasibility  study  noted  that  the 
point of equidistance from Suva lies midway between Ba and Lautoka, but that Suva–Ba traffic 
currently  uses  Queens  Road,  even  with  a  20  km  distance  penalty.  The  traffic  that  can  be 
diverted  was  estimated  to  be  82  vpd  in  1995,  based  on  traffic  counts,  and  120  vpd  in  2008, 
taking into account growth in the intervening period. 

5. 

EIRR and Sensitivity 

The discounted cash flow, net present value of benefits less costs and economic internal 
22. 
rate of return (EIRR) are shown in Table A7.6. An evaluation period of 25 years has been used, 
covering a 2-year construction period and the design life of the road before major rehabilitation. 
The diverted traffic and producer surplus benefits are estimated for the subproject as a whole, 
and are  added  to  the  benefits  to  normal and  generated  traffic  calculated  on  a  link basis  using 
the HDM model. The EIRR is calculated to be 12.2%.

EIRR  sensitivity  has  been  estimated  with  respect  to  changes  in  the  values of  some  of 
23. 
the major inputs. The switching values (the change needed in the variable to give an EIRR of 
12%)  and  sensitivity  indexes  (the  percentage  change  in  the  EIRR  divided  by  the  percentage 
change  in  the  variable) are  shown  in  Table A7.7.  Smaller  values  of  the sensitivity  index  imply 
less sensitivity to the variable. In view of the current volatility in the price of crude oil and refined 
products, a sensitivity test has been included for a reduction of 25% in the crude oil price, from 
US$120  to  US$90,  corresponding  to  a  22%  and  23%  fall  in  the  economic  cost  of  diesel  and 
petrol.  This  has  an  effect  both  on  vehicle  operating  cost  savings  and  on  construction  costs, 
although for vehicle operating cost savings, the change in fuel price reduces both the with- and 
the without-project cost stream, so the net effect is relatively small. The fuel cost component of 
construction  is  estimated  to  be  20%  of  total  costs,  so  a  22%  reduction  in  diesel  input  prices 
reduces construction costs by 4.4%, assuming a competitive construction market. The net effect 
is almost neutral, a small increase in the EIRR from 12.2% to 12.5%.

An  analysis  of  risk  using  numerical  simulation  has  been  carried  out  in  which  the  main

randomly samples each variable from within these mathematical distributions and recalculates

EIRR or other economic indicator to be estimated. On this basis, there is 78% probability that 
the EIRR for the project will exceed 12%, and 98.5% probability that the EIRR will exceed 10%.

Traffic  volumes  on  Lodoni  Road  are  influenced  by  the  ferry  services  operating  from 
31. 
Natovi Jetty. When the FRUP III feasibility study was prepared, there were daily return services 
to  Ovalau  (Buresala)  and  to  Nabouwalu,  and  a  single  service  per  week  to  Savusavu,  all 
operated  by  Patterson  Brothers  Shipping.  At  that  time,  ferry  services  were  estimated  to 
contribute about 40 heavy trucks per day. Patterson Brothers continues to operate from Natovi, 
running  a  daily  service  to  Savusavu,  and  there  have  been  disputes  with  other  operators 
regarding  berth  occupancy  at  Natovi,  which  is  a  public  facility,  indicating  that  there  will  be 
continued strong demand for its use as a boarding point for interisland services. Completion of a 
sealed road connection is likely to enhance its attractiveness. 

 

 

  
40 

Appendix 7 

4. 

Traffic Growth and Projections 

32. 
Traffic  is  considered  in  the three  categories  of  normal  traffic  growth  (traffic  growth that 
would  occur  irrespective of  the Project), generated traffic  (new  traffic developed as a  result  of 
increased activity attributable to the Project, and diverted traffic (rerouting of traffic induced by 
the Project). 
 
33. 
Normal  Traffic.  Traffic  growth  over  2000–2004 on Lodoni  Road  averaged  about 6.5% 
(linear)  at  both  DNR  traffic  count  sites.  However,  a  comparison  against  the  1995  counts 
indicates  that  this  may  be  a  statistical  aberration,  and  a  medium-  to  long-term  growth  rate  of 
3.5% similar to that for used for Kings Road should be adopted as the normal traffic growth rate. 
The  HDM  model  requires  the  use  of  compound  growth  rates,  which  can  be  approximated  by 
providing for 3.5% growth to 2018 and 3% thereafter. 
 
34. 
Generated Traffic. A general relationship of 50% generated traffic has been established 
from other road upgrading works on Kings Road and other similar situations. This percentage is 
applied to the level of normal traffic at the end of the construction period. 
 
35. 
Diverted  Traffic.  There  is  a  possibility  of  some  minor  traffic  diversion  from  other 
interisland  ferry  routes  as  a  result  of  the  Lodoni  Road  upgrade.  However,  this  was  not 
considered in the original FRUP III feasibility study. The extent of the diversion is probably small 
and  dependent  on  ferry  operator  response,  and  so  has  not  been  included.  However,  the 
potential for traffic growth to be slightly above the base value has been incorporated in the risk 
analysis.

Appendix 7 

EIRR  sensitivity  has  been  estimated  with  respect  to  changes  in  the  values of  some  of 
37. 
the major inputs (Table A7.14). In most cases, the subproject remains economically viable, i.e., 
the  EIRR  remains  above  the  opportunity  cost  of  capital  of  12%.  In  cases  where  the  EIRR  is 
below  12%,  the  switching  values  (the  value  needed  to  give  an  EIRR  of  12%)  and  sensitivity 
indexes (the percentage change in the variable divided by the percentage change in the NPV) 
are shown. As with the Kings Road analysis, a test of sensitivity to a reduction in the oil price 
has  been  included.  The  result  shows  a  marginal  increase  in  the  EIRR  due  to  the  lower 
construction cost, which more than offsets the reduction in vehicle operating cost savings.

38. 
An  analysis  of  risk  using  numerical  simulation  has  been  carried  out  in  which  the  main 
sensitivity  parameters  are  replaced  with  defined  probability  distributions.  The  simulation  then 
randomly samples each variable from within these mathematical distributions and recalculates 
the  EIRR  over  several  thousand  trials,  thus  allowing  an  output  probability  distribution  of  the 
EIRR or other economic indicator to be estimated. On this basis, there is 90% probability that 
the EIRR for the Project will exceed 12%, and 99.5% probability that the EIRR will exceed 10%. 
The assumptions made in the risk analysis are shown in Table A7.15.
